node.title: The Moment That Janet Jackson’s Career Stalled and Justin Timberlake’s Soared
node.description: Jackson was vilified after her 2004 Super Bowl halftime show, while Timberlake’s popularity seemed to take off. Our new documentary examines how the superstars were treated after their unforgettable wardrobe malfunction.
node.content: ["Watch our new documentary on Friday, Nov. 19, at 10 p.m. on FX and streaming on Hulu.", "The term \u201cwardrobe malfunction\u201d has been part of our vocabulary ever since Janet Jackson\u2019s right breast made a surprise appearance at the end of the 2004 Super Bowl halftime show.", "When Justin Timberlake tore off part of Jackson\u2019s bustier in front of 70,000 people in Houston\u2019s Reliant Stadium, over 140 million people watching on TV gasped \u2014 if they noticed.", "It happened so quickly (the moment lasted nine-sixteenths of one second) that even some of the halftime show\u2019s producers missed it until their phones, and phones all over America, started ringing.", "\u201cDid you see what just happened?\u201d Jim Steeg, the National Football League\u2019s director of special events, asked Salli Frattini, the MTV executive in charge of the halftime show. She had to rewind the tape to be sure.", "\u201cWe looked at the close-up shot. We looked at the wide shot, and we all stood there in shock,\u201d Frattini recalled in a new documentary by The New York Times.", "Was it an accident? Was it planned? Was it a stunt?", "The ensuing uproar \u2014 from the N.F.L., from the Federal Communications Commission, from politicians and their allies \u2014 was the peak of a national debate at the time over what\u2019s acceptable on America\u2019s airwaves, and who gets to decide.", "In our documentary, premiering Friday at 10 p.m. Eastern time on FX and Hulu, we hear from the former commissioner of the N.F.L., Paul Tagliabue, and the MTV executives who were in charge of producing the halftime show. And we talk to some of the politicians who seized on the moment to try to rein in content that they deemed inappropriate.", "We also look back at Jackson\u2019s long career, which never seemed to recover, while Timberlake\u2019s soared. And we consider how issues of race and sexism mixed to consume one superstar\u2019s legacy and propel another\u2019s career to the next level.", "\u201cThe New York Times Presents\u201d is a series of documentaries representing the unparalleled journalism and insight of The New York Times, bringing viewers close to the essential stories of our time."]
